New York, October 31, 1898.
The Hon. John Hay, Secretary of State, Washington, D.C.,
My Dear Sir:-
I have the honor to submit to you an additional document to my communicarions delievered to you in person in your office Wedensday, October 19, bearing upon the present condition of the Republic of Liberia. This document is a copy of an article that has recently appeared in an English paper, and presents so pertinently additional matter in reference to the crisis in which the Republic of Liberia now finds itself that I deem it important that you should have it.
The Hon. Issac Townsend Smith, Consul in this City for the Siam Government, is called to Washington on official business, to meet the Minister of that country, and I take the liberity of asking him to hand it to you in person.
Mr. Smith has given large attention to the history and present condition of Liberia, and will also be prepared to give additional information if so desired.
I have the honor to be, dear sir, Yours sincerely, J.C. Hawkled speak every* to U.S. from No Liberia Republic 8
Other documents and letters could be added indicating serious crisis which has come to the Republic of Liberia and the anxiety with which its administration looks to the United States and Great Britain for sympathy and practical assistance. Naturally Liberia turns first of all to America, from which country came its founders and which their children have been taught to regard with almost filial affection. Next to America stands Great Britain inthe thought and confidence of Liberia, and if America can not give practical aid in this time of need the Republic will hope that her Majesty's Government will hear its plea for friendly assistance.
While in London en route from Africa to America, I presented my letter from Liberia to the foreign office and her Majesty's Government, and was granted a cordial and extended interview. The result of this interview was to the effect that England was friendly to Liberia but felt that it would be proper for her to wait for the United States to take the initative in any movement which had to do directly with that Governemnt.
9
I was given to understand that there was but little doubt that Great-Britain would co-operate, if requested to do so, in any initative movement which the United States might inauguarte in guaranteeing the independence of Liberia, and tender friendly aid in strengthening its Government and developing its territory.
To say that the hope of the friends of the negro as a nationbuilder have been realized during the last fifty years in Liberia would not be true; on the other hand, to accept the uncharitable and unling criticims of the struggling Republic which are heard along the coast from among traders and travelers, and even reiterated in Europe and America would be doing great injustice to the people of Liberia. Liberia is one of the several centres of Missionary operations under my official care as the Bishop of Africa represneting the Methodist Episocal Church, and in my official duties I have made two visits to the Republic and visited all its principal centres and sought carefully to study the conditions and outlook of its Government and people. When we consider the difficulties which the Republic has had to meet in a new, and hostile clime; their lack of wealth and experience in Government, surronded and permeared by multitudes of barbarous heathen and subjected constantly to the uncharitable critisms of white traders and travelers; the marvel is that so much in the way of efficient Government and advance in social conditions, has been accomplished. True their national domain, rich in mineral and agricultural possibilities has as yet been but little explored; but it is also true that, until within a very few years, but little advance has been made by other nations on either coast of the continent in extending practical and efficient Government among the natives of the Interior. It must also be remembered that the advance made the past few years outside of Liberia has been the result of enormous expenditure in money, backed by
10
powerful Governments, able to command the best administrative talent.
The moral obligation of the United State to Liberia is unquestioned. For more than two generations a large number of prominent philanthropists and statesmen in America, have done what they could by moral and financial aid to help Liberia. Several of the great church organizations of this country have expended large sums of money and sent out scores of missionary ministers and teachers for the Liberian people. We have over nine millions of negroes in America among whom there is a profound sentiment that in some way they are to aid inthe redemption of Africa. This sentiment has been inculcated into their minds for generations by American statesmen and clergymen. Liberia is to-day practically, the only open door for the intelligent and aggressive negro men and women in America to ebter upon educational and missionary work among their race in Africa. If Liberia can be assured a stable Government, if her custom receipts abd expenditures can be efficiently administred, if she can have aid in the development of her educational system, if her domain can be explored and lines of communication be opened up between different portions of her territory, if her mineral and aggricultureal possibilities can be developed; in short, if United States or England alonf or in co-operation with each other, will now hear the cry of Liberia for protection, encouragment and such practical assistance as can be easily and properly given, there will be no question not only as to the permant success of Liberia as a Government but also the way will be opened for many of our Afro-Americans to have honorable share in the redemption of the land of their fathers.
The request of the Liberian Government is, that a treaty be negotiable that will guarantee the indpendence of that Republic and the integrity of its territory. Such a treaty if once promulgated would end all
11
anxiety on the part of the struggling Republic as to other nations who are now anxious to secure its territory; it would greatly improve the Republic's financial standing and possibilities; and would stregthen every element od its Government, as well as easy, social, educational and religious endeavor among its people.
Among the practical results likely to be assured from such a treaty might be named the following:-
(1) The Naval vessels of the United States would visit the Liberian ports and ther would be such interchnage of National and Social amenities as would have a large moral effect upon the surronding heathen tribes.
(2) If thought desirable on the part of the United States a coaling station with suitable adjacent lands could be established at Cape Palmas or Monrovia.
(3) Scientific eploring expeditions with the co-opertation and possible direction of Americans or Englishmen could be carried out.
(4) American capital would be encouraged to enter Liberia and would no doubt find profitable investment
(5) A very great impetus would be given to educational and church work throughout the Republic new being carried on by benevolent and church organizations in America.
Africa, outside of the Republic of Liberia. which Republic is about as large as the state of Nebraska, is rapidly passing under the rule of European white Governments. Liberia the offspring of American philanthrophy and co-operation is the only civilized Government in Africa, controlled and manned by negroes, and upon that Government the friends of the negro throughout the world have looked with great anxiety. America is morally bound to co-operation in every way possible to insure the success of the experiment. Recently in
12
the most marvelous manner America has assumed broader and larger relations to the world and its people outside of her own domain, and this appeal from Liberia comes at a time when the responsibilities and duties of America to the needt of other lands, have been most powerfully impressed upon the National heart and conscience.
I will sail for Africa within a few weeks and my first point of Episcopsl visitation will be Liberia. Any service which it is in my power to render in behalf of Liberia to you, my dear Sir, as representing the United States, shall be gladly given. and may I not hope that I may be permitted to bear to the Liberian Government, assurances that in the near future steps may be taken looking to the establishment of a treaty such as has been suggested.
I have the honor to be, my dear Sir, Sincerely yours, J.C.Hawkeld, British of Africa and speak Every on behalf of Liberian Government
P.S.- I hereth have to you a copy of the official pro** of the Liberia Annual Conference of the Northwest Episocal Church, which be od you in **(unclear) in quiry information concerning our part of church and educational n** a Liberia.
LIBERIA
From our Liverpool Correspondent
The sad murder of two French travelers in the territories of the Liberian Republic has provided the French Government with a powerful and singularly opportune weapon in the furtherance with a powerful and encroachment upon that Negro State. The German Emperor has recently shown to the world to what excellent use, in the shape of territorial aggrandizement, the assassination of a few missionaries may be pit; and although Messrs. Bailly-Forfillere and Pauly were not missionaries, their deaths may be turned to an equally good account, for, both with the Chinese Empire and the Republic of Liberia, the possibilities of a successful resistance to preposterous demands for compensation are not perceptible.
I do not know whether the French Government has demanded compensation from the Republic. But the designs of France on Liberia have become so palpable during the last few years that it would be displaying a crass stupidity not to take very serious notice of this incident in light of the consequences to which it may give arise.
As most people know, Liberia is an indpendent Negro Republic which owers its inception to the philanthropic insitincts to the people of the United States, following in the wake of our own somewhat similar efforts in Sierra Leone. A colony of freed American negroes was gradually formed at Monrovia and various other points on the Grain Coast, and in 1847 the colonists were endowed with the consitution of the United States. Ever since, the Liberian Republic has eked out a somewhat miserable exsistence, falling every year deeper into debt, and conclusively providing in a thousand ways that the American negro lacks the elementary principles of self-government, being deficient in the very essentialties of constructive administration. certain foreign powers
1
have endeavored to take advantage of the utter incapacity of the Liberians, and their motives in doing so are not far to seek. Not only are the territories owned by the Liberian Republic quite exceptionally rich in West African products, but it so happens that the Liberian coast is the home of the very best labor which West Africa can produce. The fame of thr Krooby is proverbial; without his magnigicent muscles and his cheerful willingness to work, our colonie would suffer most severely; it would be almost impossible for merchants to carry on several deprived, to their disadvantage, of native firemen and stokers. French and Geerman Intrigues.
It must be perfectly obvious to all those who are in any way interested in this question that for years past two great Powers, France and Germany, have been silently, and without undue osentation, working to get Liberia under their control. Whether there be collusion between them in this particular case is uncertain, but as Franco-German interests work harmoniously together in other parts of Africa, the hypothesis is by no means an unlikely one. However, that may be, France as is customary with her, is seeking to attain her ends through political action; Germany principally by commerical transactions on a large scale. The former hopes to estalbish, if, indeed, she has not already established a sort of right of pre-emption over the whole of the Liberian territory, filching here and there a slice when the opportunity presents itself. Germany is endeavoring to get the finances of this unfortunate State into her own hads, and, what perhaps is more dangerous still, trying to obtain a monopoly over Kroo labour throughout the territories of the Republic.
2
French intrigues in Liberia are not of yesterday. In 1879 a very definite rumer arose that France had offered protections to Liberia, which would probably have been accepted by the latter had not the American Government, ever mindful of its inexperienced offspring stepped in and intimated to the French Government that such a course would be viewed with disfavour in the States. In 1884 the rumours were renewed, and we find United States informing M. Roustan (French Minister at Washington) that "Liberia, although not a colony of the United States, began its independent career as an offshoot of that country, which bore to it a quasi- parental relationship, which authorized the United States to interpose its good offices in any contest between Liberia and a foreign State, and that a refusal to give the United States an opportunity to be heard for this purpose would make an unfavorable impression on the minds of the Government and the people of the United States." Again, in 1887, on the reported French aggression in Liberian territory, the United States were compelled to draw attention of the French Government to the fact that their relations with the Republic of Liberia had not changed, and that they still felt justified in employing their good offices on her behalf.
The Treaty of '92. For five years the French desisted from their efforts. But on December 8, 1892, they succeeded in inducing the foolish legislators of Liberia to accept a treaty by which France, while making some so called concessions in the interior, which the French knew would be no more use to Liberia than tot he Emperor Menelik, grabbed a large slice of Liberian territory between the San Pedro and Cavally Rivers, substituting the latter river for the former as the boundary between the French possessions
3
on the Ivory Coast and Liberia. By this means a valuable portion of Liberia territory became French. And, to accentuate the irony of the situation France is now repudating her 'Concessions" in the interior to Liberia, on the plea that added geographical knowledge has materially altered the conclusions upon which the arrangement was based.
But the treaty did more than that. There can be no doubt as to the motives of the policy which dictated Article V. of the Franco-Liberian Agreement, nor that M. Hanotaux, in getting it accepted, showed his usual diplomatic skill. The translation of Article V. (the text is in French) reads as follows:-
In recognizing to the Republic of Liberia the limits which have now been fixed (after stripping Liberia of part of her dominions France graciously allows her to retain the rest) the Government of the French Republic declares that it only intends building itself towards the Republic of Liberia, free and independent, and makes all its reserves in case this independence were to be impaired or in the event that the Republic of Liberia should alienate any part of the territories which are recognized to her by the present Convention.
The designs of France are at once disclosed in the above Article. If Liberia wishes at any time to dispose of a portion of her territory to another power, France tears up the Convention, and reserves herself the right to take any action which may seem fit to her. In other words, it is a distinct threat to Liberia never to cede any of her territory to anybody but France, under penalty of diplomatic remonstrance, followed by physical action, which would obviously entail more land-grabbing.
4
GERMAN CONCESSION-HUNTERS.
We must now turn to German proceedings in the Republic. Her merchants and her traders have been worming themselves for years past into the very vitals of Liberia. Rubber concessions, coffee concessions, territorial concessions of all kinds obtained by the judicial expenditure of "palm pil"; loans contracted; a gradual but steady grip closing round the finances of the country; and now the boldest stroke of all, the purchase by a German firm of the monopoly of recruiting and shipping Krooboys all along the Liberian coast. Small wonder that this latest barefaced attempt to capture the free labour market of West Africa has evoked a spirited protest from the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce.
Now it is necessary that the Governments of Great Britain and of the United States should look this matter squarely in the face. I have shown, I think conclusively, that the future of Liberia is being gravely compromised by French and German action. "Her very independence is at stake, and the freedom of her subjects imperilled. Are the statesmen of the United States, who in 1879, in 1884, and again in 1887, forbade outside interference with Liberian affairs- are they prepared in 1898 to acquiesce in Liberia becoming an extension of the French Ivory Coast? As for Great Britain her duty is clear. She should refuse peremptorily and at once to countenance any sort or kind of arrangement which places restrictions on the free recruiting of Krooboys on the Liberia Coast. That done, London and Washington must arrive at an understanding which shall save Liberia both from the incompetence of her own legislators, and from becoming a prety to the cupidity of the Continental Powers.
